Civil Appeals No. 3017 of 1997t with Nos. 2696-97 of 2003, decided on November 20, 2003 A Constitution of India -Arts. 19(1)(g) & (6) & 47 and Sch. VII List II Entry 8 - Trade or business in intoxicating liquor - Nature of - Held (per majority), it is well settled that trade in liquor is not a fundamental right - a b It is a privilege of the State, which it parts with for revenue consideration - Moreover, trade in liquor is considered inherently noxious, pernicious and is c res extra commercium - Held (per B.N. Agrawal, J., dissenting), decisions of the Supreme Court in this regard including those rendered by Constitution Benches strike different notes - Legislature being the final arbiter as to the morality or otherwise of civilised society, has also to state as to business in which article(s) would be criminal in nature - Regulatory statutes are enacted in conformity with Art. 19(6) to deal with those trades also which are inherently noxious and pernicious in nature - Once regulations d restricting the right to carry on business in potable liquor are attributed to the reasonable restrictions and public interest clause in Art. 19(6), the fundamental right to carry on said trade under Art. 19 is conceded - Held (per S.B. Sinha, J., dissenting), law is not to be laid down having regard to the perceptions of a judge but on premises having a solid foundation therefor, both on facts as well as in law - Courts cannot interpret equality, e freedom and commerce clauses of the Constitution in such a manner as to take away the rights and obligations created under a statute on the ground of public morality or otherwise as "legislature" as contradistinguished from "judiciary" is supposed to be the authority to consider the morality or otherwise of certain things prevailing in society - Moreover, the judiciary cannot cling to age-old notions of any underlying philosophy - It has to move with the times - Globalisation and international treaties and f covenants cannot be ignored - Supreme Court cannot shut its eyes to the fact that except the State of Gujarat, no other State has imposed complete prohibition - In fact, States are encouraging liberalisation to a large extent - Society has accepted pub culture in metros -A fresh view in the matter, therefore, is required to be taken having regard to the changing scenario on the basis of ground reality and not on the basis of centuries' old maxims - Right to carry on trade in liquor is a fundamental right within the meaning g of Art. 19(1)(g) - Moreover, the State in its discretion, having regard to Art. 47, may part with its right or exclusive privilege to trade in liquor, but once it does so, said trade would no longer be res extra commercium - Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 28 SUPREME COURT CASES (2004) 11 sec on doctrine of sub silentio or per incuriam without assigning specific reasons therefor In the State of Punjab, the grant of liquor licences is governed by the Punjab a Excise Act, 1914 ("the Punjab Act") and various rules and orders framed under it. Under the Punjab Liquor Licence Rules, 1956, there are 21 types of licences which are prescribed. If a person wants to carry on a wholesale trade in liquor in the State of Punjab, he would have to: (a) Obtain an L-1 licence for which he would have to pay the fees in accordance with the policy carried on for the period. (b) On the liquor purchased by the wholesaler, he will have to pay duty b on all purchases irrespective of the source of the product. This duty is the duty under Order 5 of the Punjab Excise Fiscal Orders, 1932, in relation to beer. (c) In case the licensee seeks a pennit to bring in imported alcohol, he would have to pay, as a condition of the permission to import under Section 16(b) read with Section 19 of the Punjab Act, an import pass fee, at such c sum fixed by the Government. Under the provisions of the Punjab Liquor Permit and Pass Rules, 1932, the State Government issued permits in Form L-32, in the case of import and the licensees were liable to pay the permit fee at the prescribed rate. On imported goods there are two independent imposts, namely, duty equal to the local excise duty under Order 5 and an import fee under Order 1-D of the Punjab Excise Fiscal Orders, 1932. The respondent in Civil Appeal No. 3017 of 1997 carried on wholesale trade d in the State of Punjab and was holding an L-1 licence i.e. wholesale and retail vend of foreign liquor to trade only. The State Government had incorporated as one of the terms and conditions on L-1 holders payment of import fees also at the prescribed rate as per the Punjab Excise Fiscal Orders, 1996. The respondent had been accepting the terms and conditions from 1992 onwards; and acting on the same, the licence had been renewed on a yearly basis. Civil Appeal No. 3017 of 1997 was filed by the State of Punjab against the e impugned judgment of the Division Bench of the Punjab and Haryana High Court dated 17-1-1997 in Writ Petition (Civil) No. 5358 of 1996. The said writ petition was filed by Respondent 1 in this appeal, namely, Mis Devans Modem Breweries Ltd., Ludhiana praying for issuance of a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing the imposition of import fee on beer vide Order 1-D(iii) of the Punjab Excise Fiscal Orders, 1932, amended from time to time, the latest amendment being by notification dated 27-3-1996, which was impugned in the f writ petition, and for other consequential prayers. The Punjab and Haryana High Court, by its impugned order had quashed the notification dated 27-3-1996 on two grounds viz.: (i) that the State had no power to levy such tax under the Punjab Act, and (ii) that in view of the Constitution Bench decision of the Supreme Court in Kalyani Stores, AIR 1966 SC 1686, the imposition of duty was ultra vires Article 301 of the Constitution. Civil Appeals Nos. 2696 and 2697 of 2003 were filed by Penguin Alcohols g (P) Ltd. and others against the State of Kerala against the common judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated 6-4-2001 in Writ Appeals Nos. 3 and 10 of 2001, dismissing the appeal filed by them. The original petitions were filed by the appellants against a notification issued by the State of Kerala under the Abkari Act, 1077 ("the Abkari Act") enhancing the rate of import fee from Rs 2 per proof litre to Rs 5 on Indian-made foreign liquor ("IMFL"). The import fee was h initially levied under government order, GO(MS) No. 57/92/TD dated 31-12- 1992. The High Court did not enter into the question of the applicability of Article 301 of the Constitution vis-a-vis effect of imposition of such import duty on potable liquor. A three-Judge Bench of the Supreme Court had made a reference to a Constitution Bench for deciding as to whether, having regard to the decisions of the Constitution Benches of the Supreme Court in Chamarbaugwala, AIR 1957 SC 699, Har Shankar, (1975) 1 SCC 737 and Khoday Distilleries, (1995) 1 SCC 574, the principles laid down in Kalyani Stores, AIR 1966 SC 1686, wherein Article 301 of the Constitution had been implicitly* held to be applicable to trade in liquor, was correct. The matter was referred to a Constitution Bench for disposal. The matter came up for disposal before the present Bench. In both the appeals, common questions arose for consideration and hence they were heard together and so have been disposed of by these common judgments. The points that arose for consideration in both the appeals were: (a) Whether the import fee levied is the price for parting with the privilege given to the importer of liquor to import liquor into the State and, therefore, it is within the competence of the State to impose import fee. (b) Whether the imposition of import fee on liquor restricts, in any way, trade, commerce and intercourse among the States. Allowing the appeal of the State in the Punjab appeal, and dismissing the appeal of the writ petitioners in the Kerala appeal, the Supreme Court Held: Per majority* It is well settled by a catena of decisions that trade in liquor is not a fundamental right. It is a privilege of the State. The State parts with this privilege for revenue consideration. (Para 103) The permissive privilege to deal in liquor is not a "right" at all. Articles 301- 304 are therefore rendered inapplicable at the threshold to the activity in question. Further, there is not even a single judgment which upholds* the applicability of Articles 301-304 to the liquor trade. On the contrary, numerous judgments expressly hold these articles to be inapplicable to trade, commerce and intercourse in liquor. (Para 113) The freedom guaranteed by Article 301 is not available to liquor because it is a noxious substance injurious to public health, order and morality. Therefore regulation in the interest of public health and order takes the case out of Article 301: regulation for the purpose of Article 301 not being confined to such regulations alone which will facilitate the trade. (Paras 141, 145 and 116) The decision of the Supreme Court in the case of Kalyani Stores*, AIR 1966 SC 1686, is not applicable to the facts of the present case. The Punjab Act is an existing law under Article 366( 10) of the Constitution and its continued application is saved by Article 372 thereof. It is also saved by Article 305 from :j: Ed.: In Kalyani Stores the case was decided on the implicit basis that Articles 301 to 304 are applicable to trade in liquor. The question was not specifically addressed. Even though there was partial disagreement between the two Judges who gave opinions, no disagreement is discernible with respect to this issue. * Ed.: Majority opinion is by Dr. Ar. State of Orissa , AIR 1966 SC 1686 : (1966) 1 SCR 865, clarified and distinguished In the Punjab case the right to import liquor is dependent on the issue of an import permit on payment of the import fee as consideration for parting with the State's exclusive privilege to import the liquor. It is purely a contractual dealing c between the State and the importer and, therefore, no question of violation of Article 301 can arise. The importer had no anterior right to import liquor and hence cannot complain of any violation of Article 301 at that stage as right to trade in liquor is not a fundamental right. His right to import is referable to the import permit which he acquired on payment of the import fee. No further impediment has been created in the import of the liquor, so that Article 301 is not attracted in relation to the payment of the import fee which was prior to getting d his privilege of importing. (Para 116) Per B.N. Agrawal, J. ( dissenting) Trade in liquor if a fundamental right A combined reading of clauses (1) and (6) of Article 19 makes it clear that a citizen has a fundamental right to carry on any trade or business and the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right in the interest e of the general public. It is, therefore, obvious that unless dealing in liquor is excluded from "trade or business" , a citizen has a fundamental right to deal in that commodity . The decisions of the Supreme Court including those rendered by the Constitution Benches strike different notes. They at times stand poles apart. Inconsistencies and contradictions in the said decisions are galore. Some later Constitution Bench decisions although took note of the earlier Constitution Bench decisions, only sought to distinguish the same and did not refer the matter f to a larger Bench for consideration of correctness of one view or the other. Proceeding on the premise that some of the principles in Khoday, (1995) 1 SCC 574, are correct, although one may have strong reservations even in this behalf, in Khoday expressly or by necessary implication fundamental right to deal in any goods is accepted. The only exception which was made are those commodities business of which is inherently noxious and pernicious and is condemned by g civilised society. It has sought to lay down the law that there cannot be a business in crime. (Paras 37 and 47) State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsam, AIR 1951 SC 318 : 1951 SCR 682 : (1951) 52 Cri LJ 1361; Cooverjee B. Excise & Taxation Commr., (1975) 1 SCC 737: AIR 1975 SC 1121 : (1975) 3 SCR 254; State of M.P. v. Nandlal Jaiswal , (1986) 4 SCC 566; Khoday Distilleries Ltd. v. State of Kamataka, (1995) 1 SCC 574, referred to Dealing in a commodity which is governed by a statute cannot be said to be inherently noxious and pernicious. A society cannot condemn a business nor there exists a presumption in this behalf if such business is permitted to be carried out under statutory enactments made by the legislature competent therefor. The legislature being the final arbiter as to the morality or otherwise of civilised society, has also to state as to business in which article(s) would be criminal in nature . The society will have no say in the matter. The society might have a say in the matter which could have been considered in a court of law only under a common-law right and not when the rights and obligations flow out of statutes operating in the field. Health, safety and welfare of the general public may again be a matter for the legislature to define and prohibit or regulate by legislative enactments. Once the regulations restricting the right to carry on business in potable liquor are attributed to the reasonable restrictions and public interest clause contained in Article 19(6) of the Constitution, the fundamental right to carry on trade under Article 19 is conceded. Once such a right is conceded, it cannot be said that although a person has a fundamental right to carry on trade or business for the purpose of Article 19(1)(g), subject to imposition of reasonable restrictions by a law made in terms of Article 19(6), he does not have such a right in terms of Article 301 of the Constitution or for that matter Article 14 thereof. (Paras 48 and 55) The courts while interpreting a statute would not take recourse to such interpretation whereby a person can be said to have committed a crime although the same is not a crime in terms of the statutory enactment. Whether dealing in a commodity by a person constitutes a crime or not can only be the subject-matter of a statutory enactment. (Para 48) The Excise Acts enacted by the States mandate liquor licensees to carry on their activities in tenns of the conditions of licence and the provisions contained therein. Article 4 7 of the Constitution empowers the State to impose prohibition. Once a prohibition is imposed by any State in exercise of the said powers, indisputably no person will have any right to deal in potable liquor. However, so long as the business activities of the licensees are within the four corners of the conditions of the licence and the provisions of the Licensing Act, they, without any obstruction whatsoever, are entitled to carry on their trade, business or commerce . They would be liable to be proceeded against for commission of an offence only in the event they violate the statutory provisions wherefor the statute itself provides for imposition of penalty. Thus, when a person has been granted a licence strictly in conformity with the Excise Act to carry on his business activities in terms of the statute operating in the field, the same can neither be termed as pernicious, obnoxious and injurious to health, safety and welfare of the general public. No public interest can be inferred by any court of law by going beyond the statutory provisions. Even monopoly of the State either in itself or in any agency created by it for manufacture, possession, sale and distribution of liquor can be created only by a statute which must conform to the provisions of Article 19(6) of the Constitution i.e. by making a valid law, by way of a regulatory legislative enactment. Once it is held that the principle of res extra commercium is not applicable, the decisions in Kalyani Stores, AIR 1966 SC a 1686, H. Anraj, (1986) 1 SCC 414 and Bhailal Bhai, AIR 1964 SC 1006, having been rendered by a Constitution Bench would constitute binding precedents. (Paras 67 and 93) Kalyani Stores v. State of Orissa, AIR 1966 SC 1686 : (1966) 1 SCR 865; H. Anraj v. Govt. ofT.N., (1986) 1 sec 414: 1986 sec (Tax) 190; State of M.P. v. Bhailal Bhai, AIR 1964 SC 1006 : (1964) 6 SCR 261, referred to The protection from discrimination as envisaged in Khoday Distilleries, b (1995) 1 SCC 574, para 60(g), would not only operate against the State which is the licensor but having regard to the constitutional goals to be achieved by the commerce clause contained in Article 301, must be extended to another State which seeks to impose restrictions on import. If some States intend to exercise their right/privilege/monopoly in the trade in potable liquor such imposition of tax cannot be justified. (Para 55) A privilege can be claimed by a State in a "no-right" situation, namely, when c a citizen is not permitted to carry on trade. But once the State takes a decision to part with its privilege, it cannot make any discrimination whatsoever. Persons dealing in liquor in whose favour licences have been granted in terms of the statutory enactments derive a right therefor which cannot be said to be "res extra commercium". (Para 36) Applicability of res extra commercium is judge-made law. The Constitution d does not provide for it. Even if Entries 8, 51 and 54 of List II of Sch. VII lead to the conclusion that the State has the legislative power to make regulatory enactment in the spheres provided for them, the State indisputably may exercise its right to prohibit dealings in liquor either wholly or partially but if it allows trade and business in liquor by parting with its exclusive privilege, a presumption will arise, unless a contrary intention is shown in the statute or licence granted therefor, that it has not retained unto itself a right to deal with a part of the trade e itself or through its agency. As soon as a licence is granted upon receipt of a fee fixed by it, the State would be presumed to part with its entire privilege. To say that while exercising its regulatory power for the purpose of controlling the trade and business in potable liquor, it has reserved unto itself a part of its exclusive privilege would not be correct unless the same is explicitly pleaded and proved. The court cannot interpret equality, freedom or commerce clauses of the Constitution in such a manner so as to take away the rights and obligations created under a statute on the ground of public morality or otherwise, since "legislature" as contradistinguished from "judiciary" is supposed to be the authority to consider the morality or otherwise of certain things prevailing in society. New Delhi Municipal Committee, (1989) 4 SCC 155; Islamic Academy of Education v. State of Kamataka, (2003) 6 SCC 697; P. Crowley, Chief of Police of the City and County of San Francisco, California v. Henry Christensen, 34 L Ed 620 : 137 US 86 (1890); Krishan Kumar Narula v. State of J&K, AIR 1967 SC 1368 : (1967) 3 SCR 50; Murlidhar Aggarwal v. State of U.P., (1974) 2 SCC 472: (1975) 1 SCR 575 , referred to Judiciary cannot cling to age-old notions of any underlying philosophy behind interpretation. It has to move with the times. "When the nature of things changes, the rules of law must change too." This is a truism in that the legislature and, within limits, the courts should change rules to keep the law abreast of change. While interpreting changing social conditions, one must take into consideration the flexibility in law. (Paras 310 and 312) Opposition will rise to every conceivable change in socio-political-economic scenarios. Some persons are by nature conservative in their subconscious evaluation of change. They refuse to acknowledge man's power to make his own history and they explicitly reject the notion that observed institutions of interaction are in themselves products of intended human action. Thus any change proposed to be made by the lawmakers or the judiciary will meet with a certain level of opposition, but that does not mean that age-old notions are clung to. The impact of changes in society also has to be reflected in the law-making process. (Para 321) Many believe that the Constitution is a flexible and evolving document, always adaptable to changes in society's conditions and circumstances. Others insist that judges be strictly bound by its words and by the historical record of what the framers of both the original text and the amendments intended. To achieve the above goal the organic method of interpretation, which is now universally accepted, requires us to see the present social conditions and interpret the Constitution in a manner so as to resolve the present difficulties. Excise - Kerala Abkari Act, 1077 (1 of 1077) - Ss. 6 and 24 - GO(MS) No. 57/92/TD dated 31-12-1992 [as amended by notification raising the import fee under, from Rs 2 to Rs 5 per proof litre of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL)] - Nature and validity of- Held (per majority), said levy was authorised by Ss. 6 and 4 of the 1077 Act - Said levy was neither an excise nor countervailing duty under Sch. VII List II Entry 51, but a collection falling under List II Entry 8: the price paid to the State for parting with its exclusive privilege of dealing in liquor - Constitution of India - Art. 246 and Sch. VII List II Entries 8 and 51 - Intoxicants - Liquor Per majority The import of liquor into the State of Kerala is prohibited under Section 6 of the Abkari Act and, therefore, liquor can be imported only after obtaining permission from the Government in the form of a permit issued under Section 24 of the Abkari Act. (Para 116) The State has not issued any licence to anybody, including Kerala State Beverages Corporation, to import liquor. Kerala State Beverages Corporation has a licence only for wholesale and retail of liquor which will not authorise it to import liquor; and the only licence issued to import liquor into the State is the permit issued on payment of the import fee and, therefore, it is seen that the levy of import fee is authorised by Sections 6 and 24 of the Abkari Act, 1077. It is not excise duty or countervailing duty referable to List II Entry 51 of Sch. VII to the Constitution. It is a collection falling under Entry 8 of List II thereof. It is the price paid to the State for parting with its exclusive privilege of dealing in liquor which includes every fact of it including its import. (Para 116) The State has the right to prohibit every form of activity in relation to intoxicants including its import. Though it is alleged by the appellant that the State of Kerala has discriminated against it, the same has not been substantiated or established by any material. (Para 116) Q. (dissenting)- The question involved in this batch of appeals, arising out of an order of reference made by a three-Judge Bench of this Court, is as to whether Article 301 of the Constitution (hereinafter referred to as "the Constitution") will have any application in relation to potable liquor, the business whereof is said to be res extra commercium, in view of the decisions of this Court in Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. Excise Commr. & Chief Commr., Ajmer 1, State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala 2 , Har Shankar v. Dy. Excise & Taxation Commr. 3 and Khoday Distilleries Ltd. v. State of Kamataka 4 • 2. These appeals arise out of judgments and orders passed by the Punjab and Haryana High Court and the Kerala High Court. The State of Punjab imposed tax on import of potable liquor manufactured in other States. The State of Kerala also imposed a similar levy. The Punjab and Haryana High Court by its judgment dated 17-1-1997 passed in Writ Petition (Civil) No. 5358 of 1996 quashed the notification dated 27-3-1996 imposing levy of import duty by the State of Punjab in exercise of its powers conferred upon it under Sections 31, 32 and 58 of the Punjab Excise Act, 1914 (hereinafter referred to as "the Punjab Act") on two grounds viz.: (i) the State has no power to levy such tax under the Punjab Act, and (ii) in view of the Constitution Bench decision of this Court in Kalyani Stores v. State of Orissa 5 the imposition of duty is ultra vires Article 301 of the Constitution. 3. So far as challenge to imposition of import duty on potable liquor by the State of Kerala under the Abkari Act, 1077 (hereinafter referred to as "the Abkari Act") is concerned, the Kerala High Court has dismissed the writ application on grounds, inter alia, that such duty, being regulatory in nature, is not ultra vires the Abkari Act. The High Court did not enter into the question of applicability of Article 301 of the Constitution vis-a-vis effect of imposition of such import duty on potable liquor. 4. Mr P.N. As the State of Kerala has not granted any licence to the appellants, the question of parting with any privilege in their favour does not arise. Pointing to the admitted fact that Kerala State Beverages Corporation has been granted the monopoly to deal in liquor and the appellants and other traders having been selling liquor to the Corporation, the question of rendition of any service by the State of Kerala to the licensees so as to justify imposition of a fee or regulatory tax therefor does not arise. However, the minority did not agree. They read into the silence and c inaction precisely the opposite - that Congressional intent that the law shall remain as it had been. (See 135 US at p. 160, Gray, J. joined by Justices Harlan and Brewer.) 265. Thus, as stated by Thomas Powell Reed in an essay in 1938, "The Congress has the power to keep silent. The Congress can regulate inter-State commerce simply by just not doing anything about it." d 266. State laws in conflict with valid Congressional enactments are inoperative so long as the national legislation remains unchanged. "If the Constitution ... makes the commerce power of the Congress an exclusive one over subjects for which a single uniform rule is preferable, it must be the Constitution that prohibits the States from e exercising any kind of commerce power over that type of commerce as it prohibits the States from taxing the first sale of an import before bulk is broken."
